facts.text: Petition filed under Original Jurisdiction as Petition No. 315 of 1954 under article 32 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 315 of 1954. Petition under article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Petitioner is a resident of Akola in the State of Madhya Pradesh and carries on business in oil mills, banking, money lending.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in this matter is a resident of Akola in the State of Madhya Pradesh and carries on business in various lines, i.e., oil mills, banking, money lending, etc.

facts.text: During the war years petitioner made huge profits but evaded payment of tax.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that during the war years he made huge profits but evaded payment of tax.

facts.text: In 1948 Central Government referred petitioner's case to Investigation Commission under section 5(1) of Taxation on Income Investigation Commission Act, 1947 for profits from 1 January 1939 to 31 December 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1948 the Central Government, acting under section 5 1  of the Taxation on Income  Investigation Commission  Act, 1947, referred his case to the Investigation Commission for investigation and report, in respect of the profits made by him during the period companymencing with 1st of January, 1939, and ending on 31st of December, 1947.

facts.text: Commission reported on 28 February 1951 that petitioner's concealed income was Rs. 27,25,363 and tax payable Rs. 18,44,949.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission, after investigation, reported on the 28th of February, 1951, that the income of the petitioner companycealed and withheld from taxation was in the sum of Rs. 27,25,363 and the tax payable by him amounted to Rs. 18,44,949.

facts.text: Petitioner applied for settlement under section 8A of Act XXX of 1947 during pendency of investigation.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the investigation the peti- tioner applied for settlement under the provisions of section 8-A of Act XXX of 1947.

facts.text: Settlement application forwarded with report to Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: This application was forwarded along with the report by the Commission to the Central Government.

facts.text: Petitioner proposed in settlement to pay Rs. 18,44,949 in installments: Rs. 3,44,949 by 25-6-1951, Rs. 5,00,000 by 25-3-1952, Rs. 5,00,000 by 25-3-1953, Rs. 5,00,000 by 25-3-1954, credit for Rs. 32,034 already paid.

anchor.surface_text: In the settlement application the applicant proposed that he was prepared to pay the sum of RE. 18,44,949 as under On or before 25-6-1951--Rs. 3,44,949 On or before 25-3-1952-- Rs. 5,00,000 On or before 25-3-1953--Rs. 5,00,0000 On or before 25-3-1954--Rs. 5000,000 and that, he be given credit for a sum of Rs, 32,034-4.6 already paid by him,

facts.text: Central Government accepted the settlement proposal.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Government accepted this proposal and the claim for evaded income-tax was thus finally settled by mutual agreement.

facts.text: Petitioner asked for more time to pay installments, granted from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, subsequently, asked for more time to pay these instalments and this was, also granted from time to time.

facts.text: Petitioner paid total Rs. 14,00,000 from 16 July 1951 to 10 April 1954 towards tax liability.

anchor.surface_text: Commencing from 16th of July, 1951, ,and till the 10th April, 1954. the petitioner paid a total sum of about Rs. 14,00,000 towards discharge of the liability voluntarily agreed to by him on account of the tax evaded.

facts.text: Rs. 4,50,000 remains due, payable in installments up to 25 March 1955.

anchor.surface_text: A sum of Rs. 4,50,000 still remains due and is payable in instalments up to the 25th of March, 1955.

facts.text: Settlement term: petitioner undertook not to transfer, mortgage, charge, alienate or encumber properties except with permission of Commissioner of Income-tax and for payment of tax.

anchor.surface_text: By one of the terms of the settlement the petitioner undertook number to transfer, mortgage, charge or alienate or encumber in any manner whatsoever any of his movable or immovable properties, barring stock-intrade of-the business, except with the permission of the Commissioner of Income-tax and except for the purpose of the payment of the tax due under the settlement.

facts.text: In June 1954, after Suraj Mal Mohta v. A. V. Visvanatha Sastri decision, petitioner filed this petition under article 32.

anchor.surface_text: In June, 1954, after the decision by this Court of Suraj Mal Mohta v. A. V. Visvanatha Sastri and Another 1 , the petitioner preferred this petition under the provisions of article 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: Petitioner alleges proceedings under the Act imposed liability of Rs. 18,44,949 and payments of Rs. 13,99,175 are illegal, ultra vires, void.

anchor.surface_text: alleging that he had been advised that the entire proceedings under the Act which had resulted in the imposition upon him of a liability of Rs. 18,44,949 and in the payment already made of an aggregate amount of Rs. 13,99,175 were wholly illegal, ultra vires, void and unconstitutional

facts.text: Petitioner claims Income-tax authorities not entitled to recover Rs. 4,50,000.

anchor.surface_text: and that the Income-tax authorities were number legally entitled to recover the amount of Rs. 4,50,000 from him.

facts.text: Petition grounds: sections 5,6,7,8 of Act XXX of 1947 invalid, contravene arts 14,19(1)(f),31.

anchor.surface_text: In the grounds of the petition it was stated that sections 5, 6, 7 and 8 of Act XXX of 1947 were invalid and ultra vires in so far as they companytravene the provisions of articles 14, 19 1   f  and 31 of the Constitution

facts.text: Petition prays for writ quashing proceedings, orders under Act, restrain further proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In the companycluding paragraph of the petition it was prayed that an appropriate writ or direction be issued quashing the entire proceedings, and all orders passed under the Act by the Central Government and the respondent Commission, and restraining them from taking any proceedings whatsoever under the Act against the petitioner.

facts.text: Petition prays for restoration of Rs. 13,99,715-10-6 with 6% interest and restrain recovery of Rs. 4,50,000.

anchor.surface_text: It was further prayed that a direction be issued for restoration to the petitioner of a sum of Rs. 13,99,715-10-6 with interest at 6 per cent and that the respondents be further restrained from taking any action against the petitioner for the recovery of the sum of Rs. 4,50,000 with interest.

facts.text: Court judgment delivered by Mehr Chand Mahajan C.J. on 21 October 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. October 2 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MEHR CHAND MAHAJAN C.J.-

facts.text: Tax recovery based on settlement proposed by petitioner and accepted by Central Government, no assessment under Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whatever tax the petitioner has already paid, or whatever is still recoverable from him, is being recovered on the basis of the settlement proposed by him and accepted by the Central Government. Because of his request for a settlement numberassessment was made against him by following the whole of the procedure of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.text: This petition is wholly misconceived because the tax recovery is based on the settlement proposed by the petitioner and accepted by the Central Government, not on proceedings under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment this petition is wholly misconceived. Whatever tax the petitioner has already paid, or whatever is still recoverable from him, is being recovered on the basis of the settlement proposed by him and accepted by the Central Government. Because of his request for a settlement no

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability arises from voluntary mutual settlement, bypassing normal assessment procedure under Income-tax Act.

holdings.text: Unless and until the petitioner establishes that his consent to the settlement was improperly procured he cannot claim contravention of fundamental rights or seek relief under Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: In this situation unless and until the petitioner can establish that his consent was improperly procured and that he is not bound thereby he cannot complain that any of his fundamental rights has been contravened

holdings.reasoning_summary: Voluntary consent binds the petitioner, invoking estoppel against challenging fundamental rights violation under Art 32 without proof of invalid consent.

holdings.text: Article 32 of the Constitution is not intended for relief against the voluntary actions of a person; remedy lies in other appropriate proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Article 32 of the Constitution is not intended for relief against the voluntary actions of a person. His remedy, if any, lies in other appropriate proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 32 enforces fundamental rights against state action, not self-imposed obligations from voluntary settlements.

holdings.text: The contention that the settlement was made under pressure and is not binding cannot be raised in proceedings under Article 32; the forum for such allegations is elsewhere.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 32 inappropriate for factual inquiries into consent validity like duress; requires different forum.

Visvanatha Sastri and Another 1 , the petitioner preferred this petition under the provisions of article 32 of the Constitution alleging that he had been advised that the entire proceedings under the Act which had resulted in the imposition upon him of a liability of Rs. 18,44,949 and in the payment already made of an aggregate amount of Rs. 13,99,175 were wholly illegal, ultra vires, void and unconstitutional

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment this petition is wholly misconceived. Whatever tax the petitioner has already paid, or whatever is still recoverable from him, is being recovered on the basis of the settlement proposed by him and accepted by the Central Government. Because of his request for a settlement no assessment was made against him by following the whole of the procedure of the Income-tax Act.

outcome.relief_summary: No relief granted under Article 32; petition held wholly misconceived as tax liability based on voluntary settlement accepted by petitioner, not proceedings under the Act; remedy lies elsewhere
